BoE minutes stated MPC sees more indications of uncertainty over Brexit withdrawal process than a month ago especially in financial markets, while it also stated ongoing tightening of monetary policy is likely appropriate if economy grows as expected but that any rate rises are to be gradual and limited.

BoE Governor Carney said MPC cannot cut rates to offset a no deal Brexit and that house prices would plummet in a no-deal scenario, while he also stated that a no-deal Brexit could be as bad as the 2008 financial crisis. (Times/Newswires)

UK Brexit Minister Raab said Northern Ireland needs to be shift across the board in EU's approach and in the event of a no deal Britain would pay not a penny more than its legal obligations, although he also commented that EU and UK is making progress every time they meet for negotiations. (Newswires)

UK PM May's spokesman confirmed once again the government's aim is to base Brexit deal on Chequers plan and stated that a no-Brexit deal is unlikely but possible, while the spokesman added that a further ramp up of no-deal preparations will be coming in next weeks and months. (Newswires)

UK reportedly agreed to EU's request for information that could help resolve the deadlock around the Irish border issue, while reports also noted that the UK no-deal Brexit technical paper stated that Irish citizens will continue to have the right to enter and remain in the UK as now. (Newswires)

EU leaders will next week discuss whether to have a special Brexit Summit in November, according to a senior diplomat who added that Brexit negotiator Barnier does not need a legal mandate from states to negotiate post-Brexit relations with the EU. Furthermore, there were also comments from a senior EU official that the EU have worked on a no-deal scenario for months and will continue preparing for a no-deal scenario, while the official added an Irish backstop must be in place from day one and that a backstop is the only way to avoid a hard border. MARKET RECAP

The technology sector underpinned gains, with Micron (MU) snapping the recent runs of declines after apositive mention by David Tepper, who is long of the stock. Qualcomm (QCOM) was higher as it begins its $16bln share buybacks. AMD (AMD), however, was lower despite a PT upgrade at Deutsche Bank, as well as FBN initiating the name with an outperform rating. Industrials were higher, though UPS (UPS) was dragging on the sector after its new cost saving measures failed to impress. Discovery (DISCA) was leading the discretionary sector, continued its momentum on Thursday after Wednesday's news that it partners with Sling TV. TripAdvisor (TRIP) was higher after chowdah reports. Staples were positive, despite Kroger (KR) notably underperforming after SSS missed estimates, sending shares as much as 11% lower. SPX +0.5% at 2904, NDX +1.0% at 7562, DJI +0.6% at 26146.

The Treasury curve modestly flattened on Thursday, after a weak CPI report (which followed a soft PPI report earlier in the week). Yields on 2s and 3s hit fresh decade highs in the session. At settlement, most curve spreads were under 1bps lower. The US sold $15bln of 30-year bonds at 3.088%, coming in on the screws, though the yield was 0.2bps lower than the previous auction cycle. Cover was above the previous auction, but in line with recent averages. Indirect takedown was encouraging, as was dealer participation was notably lower than recent averages. US T-note futures (Z8) settled half-a-tick lower at 119-13+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 13 Sep 2018: CBT hikes buoying EMFX; ECB, BOE stand pat; US CPI soft; China confirms US overtures for fresh trade talks
content:
To download the report, please click here. If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries mixed, crude down, dollar down.
* REAR-VIEW: BoE and ECB unchanged; CBT hikes repo to 24%, helping to buoy EM; US CPI misses estimates sending USD lower; China confirms US invitation for trade talks; UK agreed to EU’s request of info on Irish backstop.
* AHEAD: CBR Rate Decision; US Retail Sales; Industrial Production and Capacity Utilization; BoE's Carney and ECB's Smets & Nowotny to speak.

* TRADE: The Chinese Foreign Ministry confirmed that the US invited it for another round of trade talks aimed at getting bilateral economic negotiations back on track. Later, US President Trump said the US in not under pressure to make a deal, accusing the WSJ of getting it wrong, arguing that China instead is under pressure to make a deal with the US. Elsewhere, Trump told donors he plans to re-brand NAFTA as “USMC,” but could drop the ‘C’ if Canada doesn't agree to his changes.

* GEOPOLITICS: An official reported the US is working on an additional "severe" round of Russian sanctions by November.

* BOE: The Bank of England rate decision came in as expected, with the Base Rate held steady at 0.75% with neither a dovish nor hawkish stance exhibited from the Central Bank. BoE commentary was largely a reiteration of previous rhetoric, with the Bank remaining in “wait and see” mode with regards to rates, stating that should growth continue as expected, “tightening is appropriate at a gradual and limited pace”. On the growth front, the BoE suggests that survey data points to Q3 GDP of 0.5% vs. prev. 0.4%. The BoE did note, however, that downside risks to the global economy have increased, particularly in the EM scope, and that the Brexit situation compared to August has become uncertain. With regards to Brexit, the Bank refrained from providing any major tweaks to its guidance, with Brexit currently being somewhat of a ‘moving target’ as the EU and UK grapples to strike a deal for their future trading relationship. Overall, Lloyds concluded that, Brexit aside, “if capacity constraints continue to build, the BoE may well be convinced to raise interest rates sooner than current market pricing suggests (Q4 2019) and potentially ahead of our own view of August next year.

* BOE’S CARNEY: The BOE governor said that the MPC cannot cut rates to offset a no-deal Brexit, according to a report in The Times; he said house prices would plummet in a no-deal scenario. Carney argued that structural changes to the UK economy in a no-deal Brexit scenario would mean looser monetary policy would only pump-up inflation further.

* ECB: The ECB did not provide any significant change at its meeting on Thursday as interest rates were kept unchanged as expected. The only small alteration to the forward guidance was on the timing of the QE programme as the ECB confirmed reduction in purchases to EUR 15bln will begin in October and gradually be narrow after December 2018. With regards to outlook, the ECB cut its 2018 and 2019 growth forecasts to 2.0% and 1.8% respectively,  as expected, confirming ECB sources reports on Wednesday that weaker external demand was posing downside risk to growth. Nonetheless the inflation outlook was left unchanged at 1.7% over its forecast horizon. At the Press Conference ECB’s President Draghi sounded more upbeat over the resilience od the economy in the Euro area and the central bank’s aim of meeting the inflation target in a sustainable way. He mentioned the Governing Council has not yet discusses the reinvestment policy which will initiate after QE ends, and stressed that the capital key will persist as a guiding tool and suggesting fixability will be in place over timing and maturities of the reinvestments. Rabobank sees two potential conclusions for the ECB action in the future; the first on would see the Council adoption gradual policy tightening if it is confident inflation will converge to target; the second would see the central bank simply ending the QE purchases, which now appears to be the main focus.

* CBT: The Turkish Central Bank stole the limelight on super Thursday, with a hike to 24.00% from 17.75%. It also combined this with an alteration to the funding provided through overnight lending, which is now to be done through one-week repo auctions, alongside committing to further tightening if necessary. While the hike itself was not surprising following a flagged policy adjustment by the central bank last week, the magnitude of the hike was welcomed, and supported the rest of the EM complex. The CBRT said that this was necessary to support price stability, as upside risks were being seen despite weaker demand conditions.

* US CPI rose by 0.2% in August, missing expectation of a 0.3% rise, which was enough to take the YY figure to 2.7%, consensus was for 2.8%. Core CPIs also came slight short of expectations with the MM headline coming in at 0.1% (Exp. 0.2%) and the YY one at 2.2% (Exp. 2.4%). The softness of the data was attributed to falling apparel prices as well as healthcare costs, while new car prices were unmoved. On the flip side, airline fares primary rents rose. Analysts a t Pantheon Macroeconomics noted that the latest release confirms that the  “inflation threat is limited” for now, and the Fed will likely hike two more times this year as falling unemployment may pose a threat to inflation in the future. 

* BREXIT: Sources said the UK has agreed to the EU's request for information, that could help resolve the deadlock around the Irish border issue. This comes following EU’s negotiators rewriting parts of the divorce agreement in order to make it more acceptable for the UK in finding a technical solution for the backstop. UK PM May's spokesman confirmed once again the government's aim is to base a Brexit deal on the Chequers plan and reiterated no-Brexit deal is unlikely but possible;  with regards to the timing of negotiations he is expecting further ramp up of no-deal preparations in the incoming weeks and months.  Similarly, UK Brexit Minister Raab said that in the event of a no deal Britain would pay not a penny more than its legal obligations, though reiterated that the EU and UK are making progress every time they meet for negotiations. Over in Europe, EU leaders are to discuss next week whether to have a special Brexit Summit in November with a senior diplomat stating that Brexit negotiator Barnier does not need a legal mandate from states to negotiate post-Brexit relations with the EU. He also added that the EU has worked on a no-deal scenario for months and continues to do so, urging an Irish backstop to be in place from day one, stressing that a backstop is the only way to avoid a hard border.

* SPX +0.5% at 2904, NDX +1.0% at 7562, DJI +0.6% at 26146. SECTORS: Energy -0.0%%, Materials +0.3%%, Industrials +0.5%%, Cons Discretionary +0.1%, Cons Staples -0.4%, Healthcare +1.2%, Financials -0.2%, Tech +1.2%, Telecoms +0.3%, Utilities +0.8%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: The technology sector underpinned gains, with Micron (MU) snapping the recent runs of declines after apositive mention by David Tepper, who is long of the stock. Qualcomm (QCOM) was higher as it begins its $16bln share buybacks. AMD (AMD), however, was lower despite a PT upgrade at Deutsche Bank, as well as FBN initiating the name with an outperform rating. Industrials were higher, though UPS (UPS) was dragging on the sector after its new cost saving measures failed to impress. Discovery (DISCA) was leading the discretionary sector, continued its momentum on Thursday after Wednesday's news that it partners with Sling TV. TripAdvisor (TRIP) was higher after chowdah reports. Staples were positive, despite Kroger (KR) notably underperforming after SSS missed estimates, sending shares as much as 11% lower.

* WTI (V8) SETTLES $1.78 LOWER AT $68.59/BBL; BRENT (X8) SETTLES USD 1.56 LOWER AT USD 78.18/BBL. Oil was lower on Thursday, with newswires attributing the moves to fears that emerging market tensions and trade wars could hit demand, despite the expected tightening in supply. The latest IEA monthly report alluded to the tightening supply conditions in Iran and Venezuela, which it says could be an issue going forward, but not at present, with OPEC production rising to 32.63mln BPD in August, near estimates. IEA also pointed out that OECD stocks had been little changed since March, suggesting the market is in balance, rather than in a deficit. Elsewhere, the IEA sees global demand rising above 100mln BNPD in the coming quarter, but acknowledged downside risks which are emerging. Meanwhile, the UK North Sea Buzzard oilfield did not restart yesterday, and Libyan oilfields and ports are operating as normal following attacks on the NOC HQ. Meanwhile, on weather watch, Florence is expected to make landfall overnight as a Cat 2 Hurricane, though is still expected to be dangerous, with winds over100mph, as well as flooding expected.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES HALF-A-TICK LOWER AT 119-13+. The Treasury curve modestly flattened on Thursday, after a weak CPI report (which followed a soft PPI report earlier in the week). Yields on 2s and 3s hit fresh decade highs in the session. At settlement, most curve spreads were under 1bps lower. The US sold $15bln of 30-year bonds at 3.088%, coming in on the screws, though the yield was 0.2bps lower than the previous auction cycle. Cover was above the previous auction, but in line with recent averages. Indirect takedown was encouraging, as was dealer participation was notably lower than recent averages.

* EMFX: Already ramped up, albeit wide-ranging market expectations and the potential for disappointment ahead of Turkey’s eagerly awaited rate verdict were merely intensified by comments from President Erdogan reiterating his opposition to tightening the monetary policy reins. Hence, the magnitude of the reaction to the resulting 625 bp hike (to 24%) was arguably exacerbated as Usd/Try reversed sharply from circa 6.4000 to just a fraction above 6.0000 and a high around 6.5500. Note also, the CBRT also underlined its independence and/or credibility by announcing that from Friday daily funding provisions will be made via the 1-week repo instead of the Lira vs Dollar depo facility. The aggressive action gave other regional currencies a boost, with the Rand also extending its recent recovery gains on supportive Moody’s comments and a SA Government pledge to promote stronger growth via reallocating budget spending – Usd/Zar down through 14.6300 at one stage.

* EUR, GBP: Also looking for some Central Bank inspiration, but half-heartedly given overwhelming consensus for unchanged policy from either the ECB or BoE, and minor if any tweaks at all to policy guidance. However, the single currency and Pound rallied sharply vs a broadly deflated Greenback after US CPI misses that compounded Wednesday’s weaker than forecast PPI data, with the added impetus of positive Brexit headlines (EU will decide soon on a special November summit, UK said to be willing to provide more detail for Brussels and Raab confident about deal prospects). Eur/Usd cleared 1.1650 and offers around 1.1680 to pierce its 100 DMA and touch 1.1700, while Cable climbed through near term resistance between 1.3080-85 to trade up at 1.3120, with Eur/Gbp nudging beyond 0.8900.

* AUD: Buoyed by strong Aussie labour data overnight (albeit not consistently) the Aud led rival G10s from the outset vs its US counterpart and appears to be breaking stiff resistance around 0.7200, though still prone to any adverse US-China or global trade, tariff and diplomatic developments, like additional US sanctions vs China and Russia due to North Korea that somewhat negates Washington’s invite to Beijing for more talks, which was welcomed at the time.

* CHF, NZD: Both beneficiaries of the latest Usd downturn (DXY down under 94.500 and its 100 DMA), with the Franc strengthening considerably over 0.9700 and Kiwi building on gains above 0.6550.

* CAD, JPY: Bucking the general trend of outperforming vs the Greenback or vice-versa, as the Loonie lost some NAFTA-related momentum and slipped back to ~1.3000, while the Jpy lost any domestic support from bids layered between 111.50-70 and 10 pip intervals, plus option expiry-related interest from 111.50-65 to trade at new recent lows circa 111.20.  112.00 the obvious next tech and psych level.

* COMING UP – US RETAIL SALES: The Street looks for the pace of US retail sales growth to ease slightly in August to 0.4% MM vs the prior 0.5% in July. Wells Fargo’s analysts note the rising consumer price inflation could “restrain the more rapid pace of real consumer spending” experienced in recent months, and it  expects July's retail sales to be revised in August. RBC's analysts have expectations in line with the consensus, and notes gasoline prices were firm in the month which should help support the data. Citi's analysts, meanwhile, look for the the headline figure to print 0.3%, citing softer August auto sales as a reason.

* COMING UP – CBR RATE DECISION: Russia's central bank is expected to keep rates unchanged at 7.25% at the conclusion of its meeting on Friday. The meeting comes amid political pressure that is seemingly being placed on the central bank; Russian PM Medvedev this week demanded that the central bank cut rates amid the turmoil in EM, a call that analysts at Commerzbank describe as "dangerous sliding tackle," and drew comparisons with Turkey (whose President Erdogan notably called for lower rates, which may have contributed to the EMFX crisis, but definitely contributed to the TRY crisis). The central bank governor Nabiullina leaned against Medvedev's comments, however, stating that there were more factors for keeping rates unchanged rather than cutting; she also noted that there were key factors for raising the key rate, although she did not want to get further drawn into comments ahead of the rate meeting. "The fact that the governor of Bank Rossii Elvira Nabiullina immediately spoke up and confirmed her hawkish approach in a speech prevented anything worse form happening," Commerzbank writes. "In a worst case scenario this could mean that the rouble gets into a TRY-like downward spiral. In the best case scenario the central bank now has to take strong counter-measures to prevent this from happening - with higher interest rates that put more pressure on the Russian economy than would have been necessary without Medvedev’s comments."

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 15bln of 30-year bonds at 1800 BST/1300 EST
content:
The US Treasury will auction USD 73bln in 3s (USD 35bln, Tuesday), 10s (USD 23bln on Wednesday) and 30s (USD 15bln on Thursday); with USD 24bln maturing at he month-end settlement, the auctions will raise a net USD 49bln in new cash, according to TD Securities. The Fed will allow all USD 19bn maturing at month-end (the amount is below the $24bn cap) to run off at month-end.

TD Securities has noted that the US curve has steepened as of late, running "in stark contrast to Fed rate hike pricing, which  rebounded following the payroll report," adding that "while the auction may see some caution given the impending September 15 tax advantage date for pension contributions, we believe long-end demand should remain robust in Q4."

Focusing specifically on Thursday's auction, Barclays analysts point out that demand hs been easing at 30-year auctions, of late, with bid/cover falling to 2.27x in August, but Barclays says that demand for the long bond has still been higher this year compared to 2017. Nevertheless, performance in 2018 has been mixed, with three of this year's auctions tailing (Brclays says tails have been less volatile this year too).

In terms of participation, "domestic and foreign investor participation has been consistent at the auctions this year, averaging 60% and 10% takedown each month, respectively," Barclays says, "compared with 2017, participation for both groups is marginally higher, by 1-2%."

  • High Yield (Prev. 3.00%, 6 auction avg. 3.063%)
  • Tail: (Prev. 0.2bps tail, 6 auction avg. 0.2bps stops-through)

subject: Daily FX Wrap: CBRT grabs super Thursday headlines, but US CPI and Brexit also front page
content:
EM

Already ramped up, albeit wide-ranging market expectations and the potential for disappointment ahead of Turkey’s eagerly awaited rate verdict were merely intensified by comments from President Erdogan reiterating his opposition to tightening the monetary policy reins. Hence, the magnitude of the reaction to the resulting 625 bp hike (to 24%) was arguably exacerbated as Usd/Try reversed sharply from circa 6.4000 to just a fraction above 6.0000 and a high around 6.5500. Note also, the CBRT also underlined its independence and/or credibility by announcing that from Friday daily funding provisions will be made via the 1 week repo instead of the Lira vs Dollar depo facility. The aggressive action gave other regional currencies a boost, with the Rand also extending its recent recovery gains on supportive Moody’s comments and a SA Government pledge to promote stronger growth via reallocating budget spending – Usd/Zar down through 14.6300 at one stage.

EUR/GBP

Also looking for some Central Bank inspiration, but half-heartedly given overwhelming consensus for unchanged policy from either the ECB or BoE, and minor if any tweaks at all to policy guidance. However, the single currency and Pound rallied sharply vs a broadly deflated Greenback after US CPI misses that compounded Wednesday’s weaker than forecast PPI data, with the added impetus of positive Brexit headlines (EU will decide soon on a special November summit, UK said to be willing to provide more detail for Brussels and Raab confident about deal prospects). Eur/Usd cleared 1.1650 and offers around 1.1680 to pierce its 100 DMA and touch 1.1700, while Cable climbed through near term resistance between 1.3080-85 to trade up at 1.3120, with Eur/Gbp nudging beyond 0.8900.

AUD

Buoyed by strong Aussie labour data overnight (albeit not consistently) the Aud led rival G10s from the outset vs its US counterpart and appears to be breaking stiff resistance around 0.7200, though still prone to any adverse US-China or global trade, tariff and diplomatic developments, like additional US sanctions vs China and Russia due to North Korea that somewhat negates Washington’s invite to Beijing for more talks, which was welcomed at the time.

CHF/NZD

Both beneficiaries of the latest Usd downturn (DXY down under 94.500 and its 100 DMA), with the Franc strengthening considerably over 0.9700 and Kiwi building on gains above 0.6550.

CAD/JPY

Bucking the general trend of outperforming vs the Greenback or vice-versa, as the Loonie lost some NAFTA-related momentum and slipped back to 1.3000, while the Jpy lost any domestic support from bids layered between 111.50-70 and 10 pip intervals, plus option expiry-related interest from 111.50-65 to trade at new recent lows circa 111.90.  112.00 the obvious next tech and psych level.

However, Bunds have rebounded again along with Gilts and US Treasuries on the back of more sub-forecast US inflation data (CPI hot on the heels of PPI yesterday), while the Greenback has succumbed to more broad selling pressure following losses vs the Lira/EMs post-CBRT. DXY down to new recent lows below 94.500.

USD 2.50; reports SSS was positive for all retail brands and Q2 inventories decreased by USD 158.3mln to USD 786.5mln. (Newswires)

DOW JONES

  • Apple (AAPL) – Following the co.’s annual product unveiling yesterday, Loop Capital analyst Ananda Baruah has raised its price target to USD 256; he expects sales to become more favourable with the release of the relatively more affordable iPhone Xr. Other price target increases include: Deutsche Bank USD 205 from USD 175, Morgan Stanley USD 247 from USD 245; where potential increases in sales growth is cited. (Newswires)
  • JP Morgan (JPM) – Following the bank’s CEO Jamie Dimon claiming he could beat Trump in an election, President Trump returned fire tweeting, “The problem with banker Jamie Dimon running for President is that he doesn't have the aptitude or "smarts" & is a poor public speaker & nervous mess - otherwise he is wonderful. I've made a lot of bankers, and others, look much smarter than they are with my great economic policy!". (Newswires)
  • Nike (NKE) – The sports goods co. has announced French football team PSG and the Nike Jordan brand will collaborate with new attire. (Newswires)

  • Walmart (WMT), Nike (NKE) – Walmart’s Jet.com has said they will offer Nike products and more delivery options, initially in New York City, to compete with e-commerce rivals like Amazon (AMZN). Walmart Canada partners joint teams with Instacart to provide customers in Toronto and Winnipeg same-day delivery. The co. has announced it will acquire Conershop, an online supermarket in Mexico and Chile, for USD 225mln. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • AMD (AMD) – The semiconductor co. has had its price target at Deutsche Bank raised to USD 23 from USD 14 from analyst Ross Seymore. (Newswires)
  • Campbell Soup (CPB) – Activist investor, Daniel Loeb, will need support from the Dorrance family, where John Dorrance owns a 45% stake, to make his planned changes in the packaged food co. (Newswires)
  • Fluor Corporation (FLR), IBM (IBM) – The construction co. has announced the US Energy Department has exercised its option to extend its contract of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve by USD 2bln through till March 2024. The co., alongside IBM, is using AI to predict, monitor and measure engineering, fabrication, procurement and construction megaprojects from inception to completion. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE) – The conglomerate is in talks to sell its GE Digital unit to a US buyer. (Newswires)
  • General Motors (GM) – The automaker will recall more than 1mln big pickup trucks and SUVs in the US as it has said the power-assisted steering can unexpectedly briefly shut down. (Newswires)

  • Iron Mountain (IRM) – The real estate co. has added its data centre and network services to the co.’s general services administration’s schedule 36 vehicle. This will help federal officials to access the co.’s data more easily. (Newswires)
  • Kimberley-Clark (KMB) – The paper products co. has named Sheri McCoy, previously spent 30 years at Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), to its board of directors. (Newswires)

  • Target (TGT) – The consumer retailer has announced it will hire 120,000 seasonal team members for the upcoming holiday season, a 20% increases YY. (Newswires)
  • Zions Bancorp (ZION) – The regional bank has been granted relief from the Financial Stability Oversight Council from designation as a systematically important financial institution under the Dodd-Frank Act. The bank can now move forward with its planned merger between itself and its holding co. to create Zions Bancorporation, N.A. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Adobe Systems (ADBE) – The software giant is in talks to buy the private cloud-based marketing software co., Marketo, for suggested significantly more than when it was bought for USD 1.8bln two years ago. This would boost its cloud-based service and strengthen it against larger competitors like Microsoft (MSFT) and Oracle (ORCL)
  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – President Trump’s campaign manager, Brad Parscale, has called the Google “a threat to the republic” after footage was leaked of executives bemoaning Trump’s 2016 election victory. The co. has expanded its sole data centre in Chile by investing USD 140mln to triple its size and add 1000 new jobs. Elsewhere, Germany’s highest court has delayed a decision on whether YouTube is liable for violations of intellectual property rights.; a case brought forward by a music producer who has argued with the co. since 2008. (Newswires)

subject: Fixed and FX latest: CBRT overshadows BoE and underscores credibility
content: The stage was always set for events in London to pale in comparison if not significance to simultaneous Central Bank developments in Istanbul, and the calendar did not lie. Indeed, far from disappointing or failing to deliver despite latest Presidential objections the CBRT rammed home its independence with a whopping 625 bp hike that only fell short of an uber-hawkish shout for +725 bp. The upshot, Usd/Try down to test 6.0000 vs circa 6.5500 after the pre-announcement Erdogan exertions, with other Usd/EM pairings following suit, while core bonds have slipped to fresh intraday bases on Eurex and Liffe at 159.50 and 121.68 (-13 and -20 ticks), but the Dollar holding up better vs G10 counterparts pre-US CPI and weekly claims.

subject: PRIMER: US CPI (August 2018) data will be published at 1330 BST/0830 EST
content:
• The spotlight will turn to Thursday’s release of the US CPI for the month of August, where market participants will be keeping a close eye for any evidence of an inflation overshoot.
  • Analysts expected the headline CPI to tick up slightly to 0.3% from 0.2% M/M, while the Y/Y figure is expected to ease marginally to 2.8% from 2.9%, which was the highest rate since February 2012.
  • Some note the ease in the Y/Y figure may be interpreted as a signal that inflation has peaked in July, which would not put pressure on the FOMC to increase the pace of rate hikes.
  • Analysts suggest that the data will be driven by a rebound in medical prices. RBC’s analysts say energy should provide an additional boost to the headline figure.
  • Although rising energy prices have been a key factor, Wells Fargo expects energy prices to moderate going forward, while UBS sees the Y/Y rate edging lower in the coming months to 1.8% in February 2019.

  • Sees Q3 growth of 0.5% QQ (prev. 0.4%)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th September 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • TRY vs. USD weakens over 3% after Turkish President Erdogan wants Interest Rate cut ahead of expected hike
  • Oil sliding as EIA says OPEC ramped up production to cover Iranian losses
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, BoE, ECB & CBRT rate decisions, US CPI, weekly jobs, supply for the US

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly positive with sentiment underpinned by hopes of a de-escalation of the trade dispute after the US invited China for trade talks which was seen to be an effort to get negotiations back on track. This lifted most the regional bourses with Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) also euphoric on better than expected Machine Orders which grew at the fastest pace since January 2016, while ASX 200 (-0.8%) bucked the trend as financials were dampened after further unscrupulous practices were revealed at banking royal commission. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+2.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) were firmer with sentiment boosted by the more encouraging trade-related headlines and after the PBoC upped its liquidity efforts, while participants also digested lending data in which New Yuan Loans missed estimates although Aggregate Financing, which is the broadest measure for China’s credit growth, topped forecasts. Finally, JGBs were flat as focus centred on the region’s riskier assets, while stronger demand at today’s 5yr auction also failed to underpin prices of the 10yr. 

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos, with the injection to counter factors related to tax payments and government bond issuance, as well as maintain ample liquidity in the banking system. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8488 (Prev. 6.8546)

Japanese Machinery Orders (Jul) M/M 11.0% vs. Exp. 5.7% (Prev. -8.8%). (Newswires)
Japanese Machinery Orders (Jul) Y/Y 13.9% vs. Exp. 4.7% (Prev. 0.3%)

EU/UK/US

UK PM May reportedly wants to announce strict immigration controls at the Conservative Party conference to give reassurance to Eurosceptics in the face of increasing revolt. (Times)

EU is said to expect a UK shift on the Irish issue from the after the Tory party conference and have reportedly begun redrafting an Irish Brexit protocol in order to appease the UK. (Newswires)

Rebels in UK Conservative Party said to set a 3-week deadline for PM May to drop the Chequers plan. (Newswires)

Sealing a Brexit deal between the UK and EU will not be held up by the squabbling over the future of Gibraltar, according to the Spanish Foreign Minister. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Secretary Raab warned that the UK will not pay divorce bill without a Brexit deal. (Telegraph)

UK Government is to publish no-deal Brexit papers on Thursday related to mobile roaming charges, environmental and vehicle guidelines. (Newswires)

Turkish President Erdogan says "we must lower interest rates", and that this is not a crisis this is a manipulation. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Rosengren (Non-Voter, Hawk) said a recession has inevitably followed when employment falls to as low as current levels. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Equities are mixed, with trading tentative ahead of the BoE, ECB and CRBT rate decisions later on in the day. Major moves have been confined to equity specific stories, with Michelin’s guidance reaffirmation leading the CAC to the top of the bourse pile.

Despite FTSE heavyweights RBS (announcement of a special dividend) and Glencore (base metal strength) outperforming, the FTSE is leading the losses in the index space, with SSE close to the foot of the bourse after a broker downgrade.

The IT sector is the marked sector outperformer with semiconductor names benefiting from AMD’s outperformance in the US session.

FX

DXY - The index and broad Dollar are softer post-US initiatives to resume formal trade discussions with China, but off lows and relatively side-lined ahead of US inflation data later. The DXY is attempting to nudge back up towards 95.000 from 94.767 at worst, as Usd/G10 pairings consolidate before Thursday’s headline events.

AUD - The major outperformer and beneficiary of planned mediation on tariffs between Washington and Beijing, but still labouring on approaches or rebounds to 0.7200, even with the extra incentive of upbeat Aussie data overnight (August payrolls easily exceeded consensus and largely due to full time jobs). Note also, Aud/Usd flanked by hefty option expiry interest at 0.7220-30 (1 bn) and 0.7140-50 (1.1 bn).

JPY - Back to the bottom of the G10 pile on the aforementioned de-escalation of global protectionism tensions, and significantly stronger than expected Japanese machinery orders, with reported domestic offers at 111.50 revisited ahead of larger supply said to be lurking between 111.60-70, plus large option expiries between 111.50-65 (2.1 bn) in the mix .

CHF/GBP/NZD/EUR/CAD - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback and awaiting more impetus/direction, with the Franc pivoting 0.9700 and barely noting Swiss producer/import price data, while Cable attempts to build a firmer footing above 1.3000 on latest positive Brexit deal headlines (Raab anticipating ramped up UK-EU negotiations soon) rather than any real prospect of support or adverse impulse from the BoE at noon. However, option expiries could also exert some influence given decent NY cut run-offs at 1.3000-15 (1 bn) and 1.3060 (1.3 bn). The Kiwi has extended its recovery from near 0.6500 to just above 0.6550 ahead of NZ manufacturing PMI tonight, and the single currency looks more comfortable over 1.1600 following more Italian reports and denials about Finance Minister Tria on the verge of resigning over budget disagreements, but will be looking for further impetus/direction from ECB President Draghi later. Flow-wise, 1.1600 and 1.1625 expiries (in 2 bn and 1bn respectively) could cap gains, and for the Loonie that is straddling 1.3000 upcoming Canadian new house price data will likely pale vs any fresh NAFTA developments as more talks are scheduled today.

SEK/NOK - Both slightly firmer vs the Eur, and with the Swedish Krona not unduly dented by downward revisions to Q2 GDP growth given that the Riksbank has already leaned back on its rate hike path.  

EM - The Lira looks all set to grab the limelight at midday with anticipation/hype running rife for the CBRT rate decision amidst extremely wide-ranging estimates about the extent and manner of the flagged policy stance change. For the benchmark 1 week repo, forecasts span from unchanged to as much as +725 bp, while others suggest that the Bank may be more creative/subtle/restricted and tweak other official rates/corridors instead. Usd/Try poised around the middle of a 6.3385-3905 band in the run-up, while the Rand continues its impressive rebound towards 14.8000 vs the Usd on the softer Dollar overall, and with some independent encouragement from Moody’s downplaying the threat of an SA ratings downgrade.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds seem to have been under the influence of some technical sales when near term chart support was breached around 159.63-60 amidst latest Italian Government rebuttals of coalition divisions on the fiscal front and renewed pressure on Finance Minister Tria via the 5-Star faction. Indeed, light stops were tripped down to 159.55 and a gap filled before early Eurex peaks were retested in wake of rather sluggish BTP auctions. Meanwhile, Gilts actually carved out a marginal new Liffe high at 121.88 (flat vs -16 ticks at one stage) amidst more bemoaning the impact of high rates from Turkey’s President just hours before the CBRT is widely expected to tighten, and aggressively! Elsewhere, US Treasuries are mildly softer and steeper ahead of long bond supply and CPI data.

COMMODITIES

Oil is slipping after IEA’s monthly report which reported an increased level of production by OPEC to offset falling Iranian production, and weather premiums are being unwound as Florence has weakened abit more, but is still life-threatening storm surge and rainfall is still expected. Brent futures are now hovering above USD 79.00/bbl after breaking USD 80.00/bbl in Wednesday’s trade. This is discounting the potential support offered to the fossil fuel by the closure of  oil production facilities in the eastern part of the South China Sea before two typhoons hit the area.

In the metals scope, gold is essentially unmoved ahead of this Thursdays Central Bank flurry, with low volumes seen as investors hold off trading the yellow metal. Shanghai copper (+2.3%) has seen its largest one-day gain in 3 months off the back of restored US-China trade talks, with nickel (+2.6%) and zinc (+2.6%) also benefiting from the improved risk tone. 

IEA Monthly Report: maintains their global oil demand growth forecast for 2018 and 2019 at 1.4mln bpd and 1.5mln bpd respectively. Said that the global oil market is tightening up. The Brent price range of USD 70-80bbl seen since April could be tested. OPEC crude output stands at a 9-month high of 32.63mln bpd in August.

subject: RANsquawk Central Banks - PREVIEW: CBRT RATE DECISION - Due Thursday 13th September 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here. If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

CBT to announce rate decision at 1200 BST on 13 September 2018. The Street expects a hike of 425bps to 22.00%; anything less may disappoint traders

RATES: Turkey's central bank is expected to lift its weekly repo rate to 22.00% from 17.75% (range of forecasts is between 20.00% on the low, and 25.00% on the high); the corridor between the overnight lending rate (currently 19.25%) and the overnight borrowing rate (currently 16.25%) is expected to be maintained at plus/minus 1.50% (respectively).

Analysts at Barclays are slightly beneath consensus, looking for 300bps of hikes, though acknowledges upside risks to its forecast with the CBT over-delivering with a much bigger policy hike, and adds "should the CBT delay the return to a simplified monetary policy framework (i.e. continue funding at the o/n lending rate) and hike all policy rates by 150bp instead, markets are likely to be disappointed" though the bank this the chances of such an outcome are low.

INFLATION: Recent inflation data showed CPI rising to 17.9% YY in August, while PPI surged to 32.1% YY with analysts noting that the underlying momentum suggests inflation could tick-up further in the months ahead. The data prompted the central bank to state that it will take measures to adjust its monetary policy stance, in order to improve price stability.

"Headline inflation and core inflation indicators keep moving higher. CPI pressure is now broad based as nearly every sub-category continues to exhibit upside adjustments on monthly releases," TD Securities says. "What makes the situation worse, Turkey is a clear standout case that in no way represents the normality in EMs; while EM CPI has been marginally on the rise in 2018, Turkey's inflation has totally decoupled from the trend since 2016," the bank says, adding "in the past two and a half years, Turkey's CPI has tripled and continues to rise, highlighting how the nature of Turkey's price problems is fully home based." TD also notes that the current account remains troublesome, and estimates the CA deficit at around 7% of GDP, the largest in the world's top EM economies. 

TRY: The lira, which has dropped by around 40% YTD, and some analysts have argued that it could be facing further downside ahead. "Further depreciation is to be expected as inflation rises, economic growth slows down, and the CBRT FX reserves are eroded further," TD Securities observes. "In order to stabilise the currency and restore financial market normalcy, the CBT will have to hike in excess of 175-180bps on Thursday." 

MARKET REACTION: TD expects the CBT to lift rates by 275bps, which it says should support the lira in the short term (it says the TRY could see between 3-7% upside before the end of the week to around 6.00-6.25). However, if the central bank did not deliver at least 175bps of tightening, USDTRY could rise to 6.60-6.75, TD argues.

content: Shrugging off slightly negative US Treasury leads in favour of a downturn in Italian debt, the 10 year German debt future kicked off ECB day mostly on a firmer footing between 159.62-78 vs Wednesday’s 159.63 Eurex close. Conversely, BTPs are straddling the 125.00 mark amidst more press speculation about the position of Italy’s Finance Minister Tria who has reportedly threatened to quit over budget squabbles within the coalition, just ahead of hefty issuance.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

13th September 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly positive with sentiment underpinned by hopes of a de-escalation of the trade dispute after the US invited China for trade talks which was seen to be an effort to get negotiations back on track. This lifted most the regional bourses with Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) also euphoric on better than expected Machine Orders which grew at the fastest pace since January 2016, while ASX 200 (-0.5%) bucked the trend as financials were dampened after further unscrupulous practices were revealed at banking royal commission. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were firmer with sentiment boosted by the more encouraging trade-related headlines and after the PBoC upped its liquidity efforts, while participants also digested lending data in which New Yuan Loans missed estimates although Aggregate Financing, which is the broadest measure for China’s credit growth, topped forecasts. Finally, JGBs were flat as focus centred on the region’s riskier assets, while stronger demand at today’s 5yr auction also failed to underpin prices of the 10yr.

FTSE

BT Group (BT/A LN) – In the event of a no deal Brexit the EU roaming charges that were abolished last year would return. (Sky)

Sky (SKY LN) - Comcast (CMCSA) says its offer for Sky is being further extended and will remain open for acceptance until 1.00pm BST on October 6th. (Newswires)

BP (BP/ LN) – The co. is considering the sale of assets in the San Juan basin as according to an executive. (Newswires)

RBS (RBS LN) – The co.’s Chairman has said the British Govt. are unlikely to recoup their investment in RBS. He also said that the co. could use over USD 5bln of surplus capital to pay a special one-off dividend. (FT/Times)

Lloyds Banking Group (LLOY LN)  - the co. has said it has plans to shut a further 15 branches. (Guardian)

DAX

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) – The co.’s interim boss is looking at restructuring their engineering and shipbuilding divisions, as according to a source. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Fraport (FRA GY) – The co. reported record figures with passenger traffic +8.1%. (Newswires)

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Rubis (RUI FP) -  H1 net profit EUR 129mln vs. previous EUR 139mln, revenues EUR 2.4bln vs. previous EUR 1.82bln. (Newswires)

Aeroports de Paris (ADP FP)  - The co. reported August passengers up 4.2% YY at 10.2mln. (Newswires)

Natixis (KN FP) – The co. have announced a planned disposal by BPCE of its consumer financing factory leasing securities and guaranties for a price of EUR 2.7bln. The co. is to pay a special cash dividend of up to EUR 1.5bln. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

MediaSet (MS IM)  - The co.’s CEO said they are working on large M&A in the European TV sector. (Newswires)

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – The co. have said that real-world evidence confirms the efficacy, safety and benefits of Cosentyx in daily life for psoriasis patients. (Newswires)

SCANDINAVIA

Nordea Bank (NDA SS) – the co. have announced the sale of 60% of Luminor to a consortium led by equity funds managed by Blackstone. The sale is for EUR 1bln and post-transaction Nordea will hold 20% of the co.’s shares (Newswires)

Carlsberg (CARLB DC) – Vietnam’s PM is seeking discussions with the co. regarding the sale of their Habeco stake. (Newswires)

US

* SPX +0.0% at 2889, NDX -0.3% at 7488, DJI +0.1% at 25998. SECTORS: Energy +0.5%, Materials +0.0%, Industrials +0.4%, Cons Discretionary +0.2%, Cons Staples +1.3%, Healthcare +0.5%, Financials -0.9%, Tech -0.5%, Telecoms +1.4%, Utilities -0.1%.

Apple (AAPL) shares were still lower as it unveiled the new iPhones and iWatch devices at its Special Event; the new Apple watch Series 4 GPS model will be priced at USD 399 and the LTE model will be available for USD 499, iPhone XS with a 5.8inch display and iPhone  XS Max with a 6.6inch display; Apple (AAPL) says iPhone XR will start from USD 749; iPhone XS will start at USD 999 and iPhone XS Max will start from USD 1099. The shares of the Smartphone maker closed lower by 0.08%

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 13th September 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets were mostly positive with sentiment underpinned by hopes of a de-escalation of the trade dispute after the US invited China for trade talks
  • UK PM May is set to announce strict immigration controls as part of an olive branch to Brexiteers. Reports still suggest that her tenure remains under threat
  • Looking ahead, highlights include IEA Monthly oil report, BoE, ECB & CBRT rate decisions, US CPI, weekly jobs, supply for Italy and the US

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly positive with sentiment underpinned by hopes of a de-escalation of the trade dispute after the US invited China for trade talks which was seen to be an effort to get negotiations back on track. This lifted most the regional bourses with Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) also euphoric on better than expected Machine Orders which grew at the fastest pace since January 2016, while ASX 200 (-0.5%) bucked the trend as financials were dampened after further unscrupulous practices were revealed at banking royal commission. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were firmer with sentiment boosted by the more encouraging trade-related headlines and after the PBoC upped its liquidity efforts, while participants also digested lending data in which New Yuan Loans missed estimates although Aggregate Financing, which is the broadest measure for China’s credit growth, topped forecasts. Finally, JGBs were flat as focus centred on the region’s riskier assets, while stronger demand at today’s 5yr auction also failed to underpin prices of the 10yr. 

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos, with the injection to counter factors related to tax payments and government bond issuance, as well as maintain ample liquidity in the banking system. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8488 (Prev. 6.8546)

Japanese Machinery Orders (Jul) M/M 11.0% vs. Exp. 5.7% (Prev. -8.8%). (Newswires)
Japanese Machinery Orders (Jul) Y/Y 13.9% vs. Exp. 4.7% (Prev. 0.3%)


UK/EU

UK PM May reportedly wants to announce strict immigration controls at the Conservative Party conference to give reassurance to Eurosceptics in the face of increasing revolt. (Times)

EU is said to expect a UK shift on the Irish issue from the after the Tory party conference and have reportedly begun redrafting an Irish Brexit protocol in order to appease the UK. (Newswires)

Rebels in UK Conservative Party said to set a 3-week deadline for PM May to drop the Chequers plan. (Newswires)

Sealing a Brexit deal between the UK and EU will not be held up by the squabbling over the future of Gibraltar, according to the Spanish Foreign Minister. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Secretary Raab warned that the UK will not pay divorce bill without a Brexit deal. (Telegraph)

UK government is to publish no-deal Brexit papers on Thursday related to mobile roaming charges, environmental and vehicle guidelines. (Newswires)

UK RICS Housing Survey (Aug) 2.0 vs. Exp. 2.0 (Prev. 4.0). (Newswires)

Italian Finance Minister Tria threatening to quit over the budget, as according to reports. (Newswires) 


FX

FX price action mostly quietened overnight in which the DXY languished below the 95.00 level after the prior day’s soft PPI data and as its major counterparts EUR/USD and GBP/USD held steady ahead of today’s ECB and BoE policy decisions. Elsewhere, the increased risk appetite spurred some JPY outflows, while commodity-linked currencies remained firm amid the recent gains in the metals complex after the US reached out to China for discussions, with AUD/USD also briefly underpinned by better than expected jobs but with gains capped by resistance at the 0.7200 handle.

Australian Employment (Aug) 44.0k vs. Exp. 15.0k (Prev. -3.9k). (Newswires)
Australian Full Time Employment (Aug) 33.7k (Prev. 19.3k, Rev. 20.1k)
Australian Unemployment Rate (Aug) 5.3% vs. Exp. 5.3% (Prev. 5.3%)
Australian Participation Rate (Aug) 65.7% vs. Exp. 65.6% (Prev. 65.5%, Rev. 65.6%)

Turkey decided that property sales and rental agreements can only be made through TRY and not in foreign currency, while it declared that such deals in foreign currency must be converted to TRY within 30-days. (Official Gazette)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures continued to pullback from this week’s inventory-fuelled advances and eventually slipped back below USD 70/bbl. Elsewhere, gold was flat and held on to the prior day’s gains amidst the backdrop of a subdued greenback, while copper remained firm alongside strength in Chinese metal prices as participants reacted to trade-positive headlines.

Iran OPEC Governor said oil prices rising in favour of Russia and Saudi Arabia, while he added the US is punishing its allies and that Trump is bullying oil markets. (Platts)

NHC said hurricane Florence is now a category 2 storm vs. Prev. category 3, while it had earlier commented that although slow weakening is expected to begin by late Thursday, hurricane Florence is still forecast to be extremely dangerous when it nears the US. (Newswires)
 

US

NEC director Kudlow confirmed the US has invited China for trade talks. (Newswires)

Fed's Beige Book stated most districts noted concerns about trade tensions, particularly but not only for manufacturers. The Beige Book added that tariffs were reported to be contributing to rising input costs mainly for manufacturers and that businesses in a number of districts scaled back or postponed capital investment due to trade tensions. (Newswires)

Fed's Brainard (Voter, Dove) said further gradual interest rate increases are likely to be appropriate over the next year or two and that US economic growth is strong with the economy meeting the Fed's employment and inflation targets.  Brainard also noted that shorter-run neutral rates likely to run above the long-run in next year or two and that trade disputes are a downside risk and that trade is a source of uncertainty right now but does not see discernible impact on prices and confidence. (Newswires)

Fed's Rosengren (Non-Voter, Hawk) said a recession has inevitably followed when employment falls to as low as current levels. (Newswires)

Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland said officials will conduct NAFTA talks in Washington on Thursday although she will not be attending, while she stated officials must do more work before ministers can meet when asked when she will visit Washington next for discussions. In related news, there were prior reports that Canada is not under pressure to get a NAFTA deal done immediately and that the most optimistic scenario is to reach a deal next week according to sources. (Newswires)
